Identification.
Scindapsus pictus
is most similar to
S. treubii
Engl.
Juvenile plants of
S. pictus
has leaves with a crystalline texture and a smooth, dull grey-green blade variously marked with jagged silver-grey blotches. Flowering plants of
S. pictus
have falcate leaves with little or no posterior lobe development (Bogner and Boyce 1994 ). Distribution and ecology. Widespread in Sabah . In a variety of habitats in lowlands to mid-elevation. Usually encountered as a juvenile shingling climber, rarely encountered adult plants form extensive curtains of muchbranched stems pendent from the tops of tall forest trees, with the inflorescences born on the tips of the stems.
